qas.question: Who has hunting been forbidden to since early Christian times?
Who forbid to all servants of God hunting?
What pope was the Fourth Council of the Lateran held under?
What does the decree of the Council of Trent imply?
What type of hunting is unlawful?
Who was forbidden to hunt in early Christian time?
What forbid hunting in the woods with hounds and keeping hawks or falcons?
Who held the Fourth Council of the Lateran?
How is the the decree of the Council of Trent is worded?
Who stated quiet hunting is allowed?
What kinds of birds were kept by Pope Innocent III?
What kind of hunting was legal under the Corpus Juris Canonici?
What did the Council of Trent decree forbid servants of God from taking expeditions through the woods with?
What pope was the decree of the Council of Trent held under?
What does the Corpus Juris Canonici imply to differentiate between types of hunting?

context: From early Christian times, hunting has been forbidden to <a0_0><a5_0>Roman Catholic Church clerics<a5_0/><a0_0/>. Thus the <a1_0><a6_0>Corpus Juris Canonici<a6_0/><a1_0/> (C. ii, X, De cleric. venat.) says, "We forbid to all servants of God hunting and expeditions through the woods with <b12_0>hounds<b12_0/>; and we also forbid them to keep <b10_0>hawks or falcons<b10_0/>." The Fourth Council of the Lateran, held under <a2_0><a7_0><b13_0>Pope Innocent III<b13_0/><a7_0/><a2_0/>, decreed (canon xv): "We interdict hunting or hawking to all clerics." The decree of the <a9_0>Council of Trent<a9_0/> is worded more <a8_0>mildly<a8_0/>: "Let clerics abstain from illicit hunting and hawking" (Sess. XXIV, De reform., c. xii), which seems to imply that <a3_0><b14_0>not all hunting is illicit<b14_0/><a3_0/>, and canonists generally make a distinction declaring noisy (<a4_0>clamorosa<a4_0/>) hunting unlawful, but not <b11_0>quiet (quieta) hunting<b11_0/>.
